bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 1, 1928

div1.p: Carter describes the considerable hours she and Brown are putting in at the Library of the Surgeon General of the Army despite the fact that she has had tooth extractions.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 1, 1928
div1.opener:
Carbon (Report)(Russell)
(weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
August 1, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I started work at the Library of the Surgeon General
of the Army last week and are making very satisfactory progress, especially
considering the type of the references we are mainlynow seeking (mainly in
periodicals and only one or two to an author, as a rule).

Colonel Ashburn and his staff have been wonderfully helpful and
thoughtful. Miss Brown and I both have passes, which enable us to enter
the library as early as we wish and to stay as late as the light allows.
Unfortunately the Library is not well adapted to night work. These passes also
give us the privelege of working in the Library on holidays, including
Sundays, which will be a big help, indeed, has been already.

I would have written earlier in the week, but had two jaw teeth ex-
tracted Monday, the dentist and I having agreed that this would take
less time from my work than the treatments they must otherwise have. It
washas turned out to be a more serious business than I expected, however (infection of the jaw bone), and I have been “all
in” on my return from work each day. Hence the delay in writing. Miss
Brown and I are doing between seven and ten hours work per diem (nearer
ten than seven) and, thanks to Colonel Ashburn's kindness in letting me
take books home, I can generally do some extra work there even when
I've stayed to my time limit at the Library.
With very best wishes for yourself and the work, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
